instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Clean board, no history, I do have USB activity and image.

With known good LCD connected and new <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> 0V not shorted
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_D</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_A</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>ISNS_LCDBKLT_N</SIGNAL> 13V
<SIGNAL>ISNS_LCDBKLT_P</SIGNAL> 13V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> 0V <RESISTOR>R8442</RESISTOR> OK
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> 0V I think this comes from CPU

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
As per schematic note, enable comes from PCH.
If image is present, PCH detected internal LCD correctly and should enable backlight too.
Try PRAM reset 2-3 times.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: Right, never mind, there is no image, but I do have USB activity for sure, already tried clean ME bios and same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Missing image explains backlight problem then; you should get image first.

Do you get steady 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL>?
If yes, <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> must go high too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> should appear at least in the first few seconds (when chimes).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: Yes <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> does come up for about 1sec at 3.3V when Mac starts up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: Did you check 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> at same time?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> comes up for about 1 sec when booting.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
No pulse at <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> at same time?
This denotes a problem with LCD assembly, or video connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> also pulses 3.3V at boot up, flex and lcd are known good ones.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Looks like PCH doesn't get <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> signal.
May have bad trace/solder, or internal damage.
